interaction_summary:
=== Purchase Information === Product Title: Brassed Off! [DVD] Review Date: 2000/01/18 Store: Pete Postlethwaite (Actor), Tara Fitzgerald (Actor), Mark Herman (Director, Writer) & 0 more Rated: R Format: DVD Categories: Movies & TV, Studio Specials, Miramax Home Entertainment, All Titles Product Description: ["This delightfully entertaining comedy treat features hot screen stars Ewan McGregor (STAR WARS EPISODE 1: THE PHANTOM MENACE, MOULIN ROUGE) and sexy Tara Fitzgerald (SIRENS). It's the critically acclaimed story about two old friends -- and ex-lovers -- whose surprise reunion turns their lives ... and the lives of everyone else in town ... hilariously upside down! Also starring screen favorite Pete Postlethwaite (JURASSIC PARK: THE LOST WORLD; THE USUAL SUSPECTS) -- don't miss the fun of the laugh-filled comedy that entertained and captivated audiences everywhere!"] Average Rating: 4.7 Product Details: {'Format': 'Closed-captioned, Color, DVD, Dolby, Widescreen, NTSC, Letterboxed', 'Contributor': 'Stephen Tompkinson, Sue Johnston, Mark Herman, Philip Jackson, Melanie Hill, Mary Healey, Tara Fitzgerald, Jim Carter, Peter Martin, Ewan McGregor, Lill Roughley, Peter Gunn, Pete PostlethwaiteStephen Tompkinson, Sue Johnston, Mark Herman, Philip Jackson, Melanie Hill, Mary Healey, Tara Fitzgerald, Jim Carter, Peter Martin, Ewan McGregor, Lill Roughley, Peter Gunn, Pete Postlethwaite See more', 'Language': 'English (Dolby Digital 2.0 Surround), Unqualified (DTS ES 6.1)', 'Runtime': '1 hour and 47 minutes', 'Aspect Ratio': '1.85:1', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'False', 'MPAA rating': 'R (Restricted)', 'Product Dimensions': '7.5 x 5.38 x 0.6 inches; 4 Ounces', 'Director': 'Mark Herman', 'Media Format': 'Closed-captioned, Color, DVD, Dolby, Widescreen, NTSC, Letterboxed', 'Run time': '1 hour and 47 minutes', 'Release date': 'June 15, 1999', 'Actors': 'Pete Postlethwaite, Tara Fitzgerald, Ewan McGregor, Stephen Tompkinson, Jim Carter', 'Subtitles': 'English', 'Studio': 'Miramax', 'Writers': 'Mark Herman', 'Number of discs': '1'} Review Text: So, why do we do it? We devote our meager free time to the pursuit of musical excellence, many of us in amateur brass bands, string orchestras, community choirs and the like -- for what purpose?
Because we MUST. No matter how dismal or depressed the rest of our lives are, there's always an opportunity to create something beautiful, something truly magnificent, by combining our talents with those of others.
The Grimley Colliery Band is but one example of this. Each member, all men but one newcomer, is facing a crisis -- the closing of the coal mine into which they've poured their sweat and energy for most of their lives, and the uncertain future to follow. Their director, Danny, demanding and hard-headed, has retired from the mine, and doesn't seem to grasp the seriousness of the matter. "Music is EVERYTHING!" he proclaims. The members consider him daft, as they struggle to balance family, the impending union/management show-down, and finances. It's only at a moment of crisis that they realize the point: Danny not only understands the situation, but he also knows that MUSIC is the only thing that will get these proud men through the storm together, whole and with some shred of self-respect.
Pete Postlethwaite is brilliant as Danny; Tara Fitzgerald's understated performance as Gloria, the only female member of the band, gives her character a sense of integrity and honor that could easily have been overlooked in favor of more "marketable" characteristics. The rest of the cast is remarkable. Particularly notable is Stephen Tompkinson as Phil, Danny's son, whose descent into abject depression seems to mirror the daily descent into the black hole of the coal mine -- dark, dirty, and dangerous.
I liked this movie far better than I thought I would when I saw the cover of the DVD. This is less a romance than an examination of many lives made complete -- by music, by the pursuit of beauty and grace, by focused cooperation. It really doesn't get any better than this. Review Title: This movie speaks to all of us amateur musicians . . . Rating: 5.0 --------------------------------------------------
reference_summary:
Journey to the Center of the Earth VHS James Mason (Actor), Pat Boone (Actor), Henry Levin (Director) & 0 more Rated: G Format: VHS Tape Movies & TV, Genre for Featured Categories, Kids & Family ['Amazon.com', "James Mason plays Professor Oliver Lindenbrook, a scientist hoping to find the world's core in this 1959 adaptation of the Jules Verne novel. He leads his unusual party on an expedition to the center of the earth, by way of a volcano in Iceland. On the way, they encounter enormous mushrooms and giant prehistoric monsters. Produced by Michael Todd with then-spectacular special effects, the story was modernized to 1950s sensibilities. Mason gives this class, while Arlene Dahl and Diane Baker are the romantic interests. And Pat Boone is more palatable than you might expect as a secondary lead. You can watch this with your children and not be bored, and they will surely love it.", "--Rochelle O'Gorman"] {'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'Language': 'English, French, Italian, Icelandic', 'Package Dimensions': '7.32 x 4.19 x 1.12 inches; 6.08 Ounces', 'Director': 'Henry Levin', 'Run time': '2 hours and 12 minutes', 'Release date': 'January 2, 1996', 'Date First Available': 'November 3, 2006', 'Actors': 'James Mason, Pat Boone, Arlene Dahl, Diane Baker, Thayer David', 'Studio': '20th Century Fox', 'Producers': 'Charles Brackett', 'Writers': 'Charles Brackett, Jules Verne, Walter Reisch'} I first saw this on the "big screen" as a child, and was totally blown away by the special effects. I'm still amazed at what they were able to do given the "state of the art" at the time (1959). No, it's not precisely the way Jules Verne wrote it, but the basics of the plot and story are there. James Mason is the archtypical passionate professor, and quite good in this role. Arlene Dahl does a fine job in what could have been "just another pretty face" role. She actually gives it some character and "spunk." And Pat Boone works well in the student role, once he gets past the cheesy "Scottish" accent.
This is a great family flick -- minimal violence, nothing that would tempt other than a "G" rating -- and the "good guys" win in the end. Fantastic scenery, believable special effects -- a great way to spend an afternoon! As good now as it was then . . . Brassed Off! [DVD] Pete Postlethwaite (Actor), Tara Fitzgerald (Actor), Mark Herman (Director, Writer) & 0 more Rated: R Format: DVD Movies & TV, Studio Specials, Miramax Home Entertainment, All Titles ["This delightfully entertaining comedy treat features hot screen stars Ewan McGregor (STAR WARS EPISODE 1: THE PHANTOM MENACE, MOULIN ROUGE) and sexy Tara Fitzgerald (SIRENS). It's the critically acclaimed story about two old friends -- and ex-lovers -- whose surprise reunion turns their lives ... and the lives of everyone else in town ... hilariously upside down! We devote our meager free time to the pursuit of musical excellence, many of us in amateur brass bands, string orchestras, community choirs and the like -- for what purpose?

It's only at a moment of crisis that they realize the point: Danny not only understands the situation, but he also knows that MUSIC is the only thing that will get these proud men through the storm together, whole and with some shred of self-respect.
Pete Postlethwaite is brilliant as Danny; Tara Fitzgerald's understated performance as Gloria, the only female member of the band, gives her character a sense of integrity and honor that could easily have been overlooked in favor of more "marketable" characteristics. The rest of the cast is remarkable. Particularly notable is Stephen Tompkinson as Phil, Danny's son, whose descent into abject depression seems to mirror the daily descent into the black hole of the coal mine -- dark, dirty, and dangerous.
I liked this movie far better than I thought I would when I saw the cover of the DVD. This is less a romance than an examination of many lives made complete -- by music, by the pursuit of beauty and grace, by focused cooperation. It really doesn't get any better than this. This movie speaks to all of us amateur musicians . . .
profile:
**User Profile Summary:**

- **Media Preferences:** Enjoys classic movies, particularly family-friendly films that showcase innovative special effects, while also branching out to critically acclaimed films that explore deeper themes. 
- **Nostalgia:** Values childhood experiences and memories associated with classic cinema, often considering the historical context of the films.
- **Genres:** Shows a clear preference for adventure and fantasy themes, especially adaptations of literary works, but also appreciates stories that highlight the importance of community and personal growth.
- **Family Orientation:** Prioritizes content suitable for children, indicating a preference for wholesome entertainment that can be enjoyed together with family.
- **Character Appreciation:** Has a keen interest in strong character development, especially in lead roles that embody passion and intelligence, and recognizes the depth of performances by character actors.
- **Critical Perspective:** Maintains a balanced view on adaptations; appreciates when the spirit of the original story is preserved, even if changes are made for cinematic purposes. Shows an understanding of the emotional resonance that music and creative collaboration can have in storytelling.
- **Engagement with Actors:** Shows particular admiration for classic actors and performances that contribute meaningful narratives, suggesting a preference for nuanced portrayals and ensemble casts.

This user profile indicates a consistent trend toward valuing quality family entertainment that blends nostalgia with compelling storytelling and emotional depth.
